messageBody:
On Apr 20, 2013, at 3:20 PM, Nathan Sharfi <bonusfrogs@...> wrote:

> On Apr 20, 2013, at 1:30 AM, Michael Everson <everson@...> wrote:
>
>> Quikscript users: Are you comfortable reading Shavian? Are you happy that, if the two are unified, that you will sometimes see Quikscript texts written with non-cursive Shavian glyphs? Think about Latin blackletter fonts, which you can and do read more or less regularly.
>
> Let's try it!
>
> I went to http://shavian.weebly.com/ and flung my browser window off to the left immediately so I wouldn't be able to see the same thing written in Orthodox. Here's what it says:
>
> 𐑢𐑧𐑤𐑒𐑳𐑥
> 𐑣𐑧𐑤𐑴 𐑯 𐑢𐑧𐑤𐑒𐑳𐑥 𐑑 𐑥𐑲 ·𐑖𐑱𐑝𐑾𐑯 𐑨𐑤𐑓𐑩𐑚𐑧𐑑 𐑢𐑧𐑚𐑕𐑲𐑑! 𐑲 𐑒𐑮𐑰𐑱𐑑𐑧𐑛 𐑞𐑦𐑕 𐑕𐑲𐑑 𐑑 𐑐𐑮𐑩𐑒𐑑𐑦𐑕 𐑮𐑲𐑑𐑦𐑙 𐑯 𐑮𐑰𐑛𐑦𐑙 𐑦𐑯 𐑞 ·𐑖𐑷 𐑕𐑒𐑮𐑦𐑐𐑑. 𐑷𐑤𐑕𐑴 𐑑 𐑖𐑺 𐑑𐑮𐑩𐑯𐑟𐑤𐑦𐑑𐑻𐑱𐑖𐑳𐑯𐑟 𐑲 𐑣𐑩𐑝 𐑥𐑱𐑛 𐑹 𐑒𐑳𐑥 𐑩𐑒𐑮𐑷𐑕. 𐑥𐑨𐑯𐑰 𐑕𐑲𐑑𐑟 𐑯 𐑮𐑧𐑕𐑹𐑕𐑧𐑟 𐑸 𐑯𐑴 𐑤𐑪𐑙𐑻 𐑪𐑯𐑤𐑲𐑯,
> 𐑲 𐑣𐑴𐑐 𐑞𐑦𐑕 𐑢𐑦𐑤 𐑚𐑰𐑒𐑳𐑥 𐑩 𐑮𐑰𐑐𐑷𐑕𐑦𐑑𐑹𐑮𐑰 𐑓𐑹 ·𐑖𐑱𐑝𐑾𐑯 𐑦𐑯𐑓𐑹𐑥𐑱𐑖𐑳𐑯. 𐑕𐑴 𐑣𐑽'𐑕 𐑑 𐑞𐑦𐑕 𐑩𐑛𐑝𐑧𐑯𐑗𐑻!
>
> :-) - ·𐑡𐑪𐑯

Over the past few days I've noticed another set of pain points that'd be solved with disunification.

In a number of cases, "just change your fonts" is at best undesirable. My desktop operating system of choice ships with the standard Shavian repertoire in Apple Symbols, and so the Shavian text above is rendered in it even though my preferred font is Monaco. This lets me keep my preferred font for normal use, and gives me *something* so text written in minority scripts are still readable.

Of course, this is just font substitution at work, and all modern OSs have this feature.

That said, I haven't seen ways to choose *which* font gets chosen on either system. If I want to ensure that QS text in Unicode is displayed as QS in IM clients, E-mail clients, microblogging clients, and Web apps for all the above, I'd have to delete system fonts (dicey, and removes Deseret support) or edit system font files (even dicier).

On the other hand, if Shavian and QS are wholly disunified, people'll be able to install one or more QS fonts on their systems and their OSs will be able to choose something cohesive and legible, and save them the trouble of squinting at glyphs that look like 7s and wondering what they are — or having to remember that the glyph that looks like a reversed 6 is actually for the [T] sound, not [f].
